story.description:
Addition of a scope parameter to the acts_as_list in the User model has introduced subtle and weird bugs. acts_as_list adds all new records to the bottom of the list. However, new User's won't be published and so really (with the current intent of the code) shouldn't be in the list. Because the scope defines only published users as being in the list it means that all new users have the same position in the list.
The best thing to do is probably to remove the scope from acts_as_list and have one global order of users.
This would require that we:
1. update the next/previous functions to scope to published 2. update the user_order controller to deal with updating in terms of insert_dragged_thing at position x in the list instead of submitting positions for all rendered elements (we only want to render and allow ordering of published users, but non-published users may also have order and after an update positions may clash).
There may be other unforeseen things that need changing.
story.name: TECHNICAL DEBT: Revisit acts_as_list and published scope in User model

story.description:
The publish date fields in the admin area are weird. They current;y show 2 textfields, one of which you can't type in, and the other has no label, with some text under it suggesting what you can type in it.
If the JS parser doesn't like what you've written in the first text box you get a blank 2nd text box, with a red cursor.
A better solution would be:
1 text field, with a label (the name of the field). When you type in here it updates a hidden field that is the actual submitted value. It also updates a static bit of text with the result (so you know what will be submitted). If the JS parser doesn't like it, make the JS text field an error and blank out the other one. Also, maybe a button to reset.
story.name: Admin area publish date fields need to be less ass

story.description:
COPY:
Who do we Want? Unboxed Consulting runs an Internship Programme in our London offices from July to September each year. Interns will be given an Introduction to Agile and Ruby on Rails training. Ideally we're looking for penultimate-year BSc and MSc students with a passion for great software development to join our Internship. The ideal candidate should be self-motivated, creative and diligent. We expect the candidate will be willing to step up and learn things outside their current talents. A desire to learn and adapt to the Unboxed culture is essential.
Where Do They Currently Come From?
We have been targeting universities that have a Ruby on Rails module as part of their degree. Universities that we have established contact with to date include:
University of Southampton University of Surrey University of Essex University of Aberdeen Imperial College
If you're not studying at one of the above and you feel it'd be good for us to establish a relationship with your university, please drop us a line at iwantajob@unboxedconsulting.com

The ideal candidate should be self-motivated, creative and diligent. We expect the candidate will be willing to step up and learn things outside their current talents. A desire to learn and adapt to our culture is essential.
Location: Central London and Cape Town
If you want to apply for the programme, or think we should build a relationship with your University, please drop us a line at iwantajob@unboxedconsulting.com

story.name: Mobile version of the site

comment.text: Have made the site responsive, using media queries to allow the site to reflow to better fit the dimensions of the browser viewing it.

For the browsers that do not support media queries (IE6-8), javascript has been used to polyfill the lack of functionality. If the site is viewed without JS on these browsers, the site will gracefully degrade back to the narrow 'single column' layout.
Mobile version of the site is live.

comment.text:
It's done in a branch (2_3_8_upgrade) but we can't deploy it because 2.3.8 requires a new version of rack and you can't have lots of apps deployed in one passenger that want different versions of rack.
To complete this story we need new infrastructure.
Latest version is Rails 3.2.0 at the time of *this* writing....
Might as well upgrade to ruby 1.9.3 while we're at it.
I've upgraded it to Rails 3.1.6 whilst keeping it on Ruby 1.8.7. I think that's enough for the time being, and we can revisit this story after we've implemented a few more features.

story.description: Once Tom has cut them all out

Some resources originate from non-https servers, which invalidates some browser's confidence in our site's security (see attached)

comment.text:
Our current understanding is that it's probably the disqus script. We can either:
* include it with a protocol-less uri (so it inherits the current page's protocol) * always include it as https * do the same thing we do to include the google analytics script and work out if it should be an http or https include based on the current page and act accordingly.
Probably doing https all the time would be useful as disqus lobs a login form on the page and we'd probably rather that was https.

story.description: Disqus appears to store the comment against the current page URL instead of the canonical. Investigate and see what can be done.
story.name: Spike: Comments made over ssl don't appear when viewing the page over plain http and vice versa

comment.text: This is in connection with: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/26234901

I've changed Disqus to always use SSL, and I've updated it to use the latest (still a little crazy) version of their API.
The current solution of propagating the request protocol through to disqus would cause a lot of inconsistency of comments. Disqus treats http and https as different URLs and therefore has a different set of comments for each.
We should be able to migrate old comments over to the https url once we get the login details for Disqus (if we care about them). I can't find these in passwordsafe, I think Richard might know them.
It's also worth noting that Disqus doesn't work so well on a domain that isn't live. It has a 'developer mode', which wavers the url restriction. But if a blog post hasn't had any comments or likes on the live site, Disqus simply won't load because staging isn't accessible externally.

story.description:
The carousel has some issues such as: - The images are not clickable, which makes it less useful on touch devices, as the user has to click on the sticker - The scrolling animation isn't attractive and not user friendly on touch devices - The navigation buttons don't react to user hover, only when they are clicked - In desktop browsers the fading animation gets stuck sometimes and the user can't see anything where the image and the sticker should be - At the big images are used as CSS background (won't help with SEO or sharing the page for instance) - I talked to Tom and we agreed to redesign the carousel a bit. Instead of restricting the width it should be bleeding to the side edges, and all the images should have a solid background color. We don't need design for this, it can be easily done by modifying the CSS - I think all these could be done as one story as it's pretty much all linked together ---
I've done a few carousels (http://www.waste-creative.com/) in JS and I would be happy to combine my code with Carl's to fix these issues and make it super awesome :)
Let's talk about it guys, let me know what you think!

story.description:
I too am a geek, but a grammar geek, so please find my take below. I admit that some are really picky, but I have spent some time doing proofreading for publications for colleges where every tiny error had to be corrected!!!
e-petitions ‘lightening-fast development’ should be ‘lightning-fast development’ ‘It will be checked for swearing and liable’ should this be ‘it will be checked for swearing and libel’? ‘e-petitions was built in for £80k (all-in) in 8 weeks’ should be e-petitions was built for £80k (all-in) in 8 weeks’
Contiki ‘Unboxed Consulting’s skill at at adaptability within a tight timeframe and budget.’ – duplicate ‘at’
News 1. It’s interesting to see that we’re the only Ruby on Rails provider in the list. Ruby is fast becoming the platform of choice for large scale, innovative applications, highlighted by the fact that government is embracing the platform. So it’s exciting that we’re now counted among the big traditional Java and PHP players.”. Should be all one sentence, ‘….embracing the platform, so it’s exciting….’ 2. ‘We have ensured we have a development process that get the best quality product’ Should be either ‘ a development process that gets..’ or development processes that get’ 3. We have bundled all this up in a customer engagement model that gets the right product build with the minimum of fuss. And to ensure…’ Should this be ‘… that gets the right product built..’? Also, ‘and’ should be a continuation of the sentence ‘…minimum of fuss, and…’ 4. ‘Choose a team that prides itself in zero production.’ You can take pride in, or pride yourself on, so should be ‘prides itself on zero production’ (or takes pride in zero production) 5. ‘… and the product is emerging, there for the stakeholders to see, to using, to adapting and improving’ Doesn’t make sense. ‘…and the product is emerging, there for the stakeholders to see; to use, adapt and improve’ or ‘…and the product is emerging, there for the stakeholders to see, use, adapt and improve’ (but the site does look really good!!)

story.description:
The sitemap.xml file is generated every day and is used by Google when crawling our site. It has broken links in it that are not making our site looking good in the search engine. Look at the generated file on staging or production. For example portfolio links don't exist, and probably the paginated links also don't make much sense as Google would be able to crawl these by itself anyway.
- case studies (1.0) - services & methodologies (1.0) - blog articles (0.8) - news articles (0.6) - contact (0.5) - people (0.4) - courses (0.4) - jobs (0.3)

Use Whenever to manage cron jobs

comment.text:
Someone has added whenever to the project. It's only configured to run one cron job (generate sitemap). I don't know if there are any other cron jobs that need to run (I think there's something about a nightly user sync from ldap?).
It's also not clear to me if we're regenerating the cron job on deploy either (nothing jumps out at me in config/deploy.rb - we do include whenever/capistrano, but we don't appear to use any recipies directly).

story.description:
If we want to upgrade rails and ruby (see: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/4390984) we need to be able to deploy the app to different staging and production sites. After discussing this with Matt it means we need to have a migration path for switching over deployments.
All the app codebase needs to do is change the server name in config/deploy/stage.rb and config/deploy/production.rb - but the chef cookbooks need to be updated to make sure that stage3 and prod2 are configured for these apps. Care must be taken to make sure that configuring stage3 and prod2 to host this app doesn't blow away the apps on stage1 and prod1 (prod1 particularly as the dns switch will be fast, but no instantaneous so we need the app to still be available externally on both servers for a bit).
story.name: Migration path from 1.8.7 servers (stage1, prod1) to 1.9.3 servers (stage3, prod2).

comment.text: Assigning to Matt P. No rush on this as the ruby/rails upgrade is not a priority. Yet.
